column3: Activision's new 'Call of Duty' game rakes in $550 million in three days

column3: U.S. Cyber Monday sales up 14 pct  on track for record -Adobe

column3: Delphi says self-driving car didn't come close to Google's car
column4: Delphi Automotive PLC  on Friday offered a new description of an encounter on a California road between one of its prototype self-driving cars and a self-driving vehicle operated by Google Inc   saying "the vehicles didn't even come close to each other."

column3: Critics due to get EU's Google antitrust charge sheet this week: sources
column4: BRUSSELS Microsoft  German publisher Axel Springer and 17 other critics of Google are expected to get a copy of the EU's antitrust charge sheet against the search engine giant this week in order to allow them to provide feedback  four people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

column3: Audi CEO's privacy appeal takes aim at Google's car push

column3: No transaction fee for Google on mobile phone payments -WSJ
column4: June 6 Google's new mobile phone payment service  Android Pay  will not garner any transaction fees from credit card companies  which may put pressure on competitor Apple to drop or lower its charges  the Wall Street Journal reported.

column3: Google to release monthly data on self-driving car accidents
column4: June 5 Google Inc said it would give monthly updates of accidents involving its driverless cars as public interest groups ask for more data on the safety of the project.

column3: Google says 21 percent of tech hires in 2014 were women
column4: Google Inc said 21 percent of tech hires last year were women  boosting overall number of women in technical roles by 1 percent  as part of efforts to increase diversity.

column3: Airbus Group starts $150 mln venture fund  Silicon Valley base

column3: YouTube may show 'Innocence of Muslims' film: U.S. court

Google  Viacom win dismissal of children's web privacy lawsuit

column4: Amazon.com Inc is set to open its first physical book store in Seattle on Tuesday  the company said.

column4: Sears Holdings Corp named a former logistics executive at Amazon.com to a new senior role as the retailer seeks to revive itself by focusing on a loyalty program that hinges on integrating its online and store operations.

column3: Amazon announces low-cost tablet  new Fire TV

column3: Target challenges Amazon  enters grocery delivery with Instacart

column3: In North Korea  deals on the bus make markets go round
column4: SEOUL It's not Amazon or FedEx  but in North Korea's fledgling market economy a fleet of repurposed old passenger buses is the next best thing for moving trade goods  from rice to textiles and livestock  between far-flung corners of the country.

column3: Amazon jumps into restaurant delivery in Seattle
column4: SAN FRANCISCO Online retailer Amazon.com Inc said on Tuesday it will begin offering its own restaurant delivery service to Prime members in Seattle  marking its first push into an increasingly crowded market for meal delivery known for razor-thin margins.

column3: Amazon plans to sell $50 tablet: WSJ
column4: Online retailer Amazon.com Inc plans to release a $50 tablet in time for the holiday season  the Wall Street Journal reported  citing people familiar with the matter.

column3: Amazon's 'Dash' button now effectively free
column4: Amazon.com Inc said its 'Dash' button  which allows customers to place orders instantly  will now be effectively free.

column3: Amazon to launch video streaming service in Japan
column4: Amazon.com said on Wednesday it plans to launch its video streaming service in Japan for members of its Prime paid service as it gears up for Netflix Inc's planned entry into the country in September.

column3: Amazon to launch video streaming service in Japan - Nikkei
column4: Aug 26 Amazon.com plans to launch its video streaming service in Japan for members of its Prime paid service as it gears up for Netflix Inc's planned entry into the country in September  the Nikkei reported.

column3: Amazon expands Prime Now  offers U.S. alcohol for first time
column4: SAN FRANCISCO Amazon.com Inc  said on Tuesday it will begin delivering wine  beer and spirits to U.S. customers for the first time as part of its speedy delivery service  Prime Now.

column3: UPDATE 2-Vale halts Amazon nickel mine output after court order
column4: RIO DE JANEIRO  Aug 14 Vale SA stopped operations at its Onça Puma nickel mine in Brazil's Amazon after a Brazilian federal court on Friday ordered the halt because of disputed payments to indigenous communities.

column3: Amazon quietly shutters product ads that drove traffic to outside sites
column4: SAN FRANCISCO Amazon.com Inc quietly shuttered a pay-per-click advertising programme that allowed businesses to divert traffic from the retailer's platform to their own websites on Tuesday  saying it would permanently discontinue the programme in October.

column3: Growth of ecommerce pushes funds into small-fry shipping firms
column4: NEW YORK Forget Amazon and its out-of-this-world share price.

column3: New York settles lawsuits on online sales of real-looking toy guns

column3: Amazon posts anomalous profit  Wall Street swoons
column4: SAN FRANCISCO Investor enthusiasm for Amazon.com Inc  is pretty consistent: the stock tends to rise  even though the company isn't consistent about making profits.

column3: Amazon.com CEO Bezos up $8 billion  down $4 billion on stock swing
column4: NEW YORK Amazon.com founder and Chief Executive Officer Jeff Bezos got a lot richer while he slept on Thursday night  after the company reported its quarterly earnings and its shares rose 20.1 percent.

column3: UPDATE 3-Amazon shares soar on surprise profit  market value above Wal Mart's

column3: Macy's to expand same-day delivery to new U.S. markets  challenging Amazon
column4: CHICAGO/SAN FRANCISCO Macy's Inc  is expanding same-day delivery to several new U.S. markets this summer  one of the most aggressive pushes by a brick-and-mortar retailer in an area dominated by e-commerce giant Amazon   according to a Macy's official. | Video

column3: Amazon must face trademark lawsuit over search results

column3: As Amazon  eBay remove Confederate flags  Nazi items on sale

column3: Amazon  Google join retailers in banning Confederate flag

column3: Oracle extends cloud offerings  looks to compete with Amazon.com

column3: Amazon insists federal rules apply to U.S. deliveries by drone

column4: PARIS  June 15 Europe's anti-trust chief warned Amazon on Monday against using its dominance to thwart rivals  a week after launching an investigation into the U.S. online retailer's ebook deals with publishers.

column3: Google launches a YouTube built for gamers

column3: Appeals court approves of early Amazon.com win in patent suit

column3: Amazon's Europe changes to boost tax bill  add secrecy

Blue Origin  a startup space company owned by Amazon.com chief Jeff Bezos  launched an experimental suborbital spaceship from Texas  the first in a series of test flights to develop commercial unmanned and passenger spaceflight services  the company said on Thursday. | Video

column4: SAN FRANCISCO  Jan 21 Amazon.com Inc  pulled its private-label diapers to fix design flaws less than two months after launching the products  the company said on Wednesday.

column3: Amazon doubles down on entertainment with 'indie' movie bet

column3: Amgen's bone drug succeeds in late-stage study

column4: I hear that you plan to give away 99 percent of your Facebook shares - valued at $45 billion - for philanthropic purposes. What a great idea!

column3: Gilead leukemia drug trial unblinded early due to success
column4: A late stage trial of a Gilead Sciences drug in previously treated patients with a particular type of leukemia was unblinded early after independent monitors determined the medicine provided significant benefit in delaying worsening of the disease  the company said on Monday.

column4: Drugmaker Gilead Sciences Inc said on Thursday the U.S. Food and Drug Administration had approved the expanded use of its blockbuster hepatitis C drug  Harvoni.

column4: Gilead Sciences Inc said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration had approved its HIV drug cocktail  Genvoya  to treat patients aged 12 and above.

column4: Gilead Sciences Inc  on Tuesday said its quarterly profit rose 70 percent  but sales growth for its hepatitis C drugs flattened as health insurers limited access to the expensive treatments.

column3: Gilead's new HIV drug shows lower side-effects over longer term
column4: Drugmaker Gilead Sciences Inc said data from a late-stage study showed that its experimental drug  Genvoya  showed reduced side-effects compared with an older version of the drug in treating HIV-infected patients over a longer term.

column3: U.S. settles insider trading charges tied to Gilead acquisition

column4: LONDON Gilead Sciences is seeking to convince governments and multilateral agencies worldwide that hepatitis C can be eliminated with a demonstration project in Georgia offering free drugs to all those who need them.

column4: Achillion Pharmaceuticals Inc's experimental hepatitis C drug  when used with Gilead Sciences Inc's Sovaldi  eradicated signs of the virus in six weeks  the shortest duration and highest response achieved by any two-drug treatment.

column4: Microsoft Corp  reported a $3.2 billion quarterly net loss  its biggest ever  as the company wrote down its Nokia phone business and demand fell for its Windows operating system.

column3: Ohio State runs wild  stuns Alabama in Sugar Bowl

column3: Illinois top court voids $10.1 bln Philip Morris 'light' verdict

column3: Philip Morris expands e-cigarette deal with Altria

column3: Tobacco companies to settle smoking lawsuits for $100 million
column4: Three major U.S. tobacco companies - R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co  Lorillard Inc and Altria Group's  Philip Morris USA - will pay $100 million to settle hundreds of federal lawsuits over smoking  according to an announcement from plaintiffs' lawyers on Wednesday.

column4: MEXICO CITY  Oct 19 Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim's America Movil on Monday reported a third-quarter net loss as Latin American currencies depreciated sharply against the dollar  hurting the revenue of region's biggest pay TV and wireless company.

column3: Austria denies planning to sell Telekom stake
column4: VIENNA  Oct 17 Austria on Saturday denied a newspaper report saying it was preparing to sell its 28 percent stake in Telekom Austria to the company's majority owner  Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim's America Movil.

column3: UPDATE 2-Telco unit of Mexico's Alfa to merge with Axtel
column4: MEXICO CITY  Oct 1 Mexican telecommunications firms Alestra  a unit of industrial conglomerate Alfa  and Axtel announced on Thursday they would merge to better rival Carlos Slim's America Movil  which dominates Mexico's fixed-line market.

column3: America Movil sells 750 mln euros in bonds convertible into KPN shares

column3: America Movil says facing Mexico probe in blow to TV ambition

column3: Brazil's Bradesco not approached to buy BTG Pactual assets: CEO
column4: SAO PAULO Brazilian lender Banco Bradesco SA has not been approached about buying assets from investment bank BTG Pactual SA  its chief executive said on Monday.

column4: SAO PAULO  Nov 16 Banco Bradesco SA  Brazil's No. 2 private-sector lender  plans to seek shareholder approval to raise about 3 billion reais ($780 million) to bolster capital following a ramp-up in loan-loss provisions and the purchase of HSBC Holdings Plc's local unit.

column3: UPDATE 3-Senior Bradesco executive killed in Brazil plane crash
column4: SAO PAULO  Nov 11 Marco Antonio Rossi  the top executive at the insurance arm of  Brazil's second-largest private-sector lender Banco Bradesco SA  was killed in a plane crash  the bank said in a statement on Wednesday.

column3: UPDATE 1-Brazl's Bradesco sees large corporate defaults peaking
column4: SAO PAULO  Oct 30 Defaults among large corporate borrowers in Brazil probably peaked  following months of steady increases  as industrial  farming and services firms actively seek to refinance their debts  executives at Banco Bradesco SA said on Friday.

column3: UPDATE 2-Bradesco provision buffer enough to counter Brazil defaults
column4: SAO PAULO  Oct 29 Banco Bradesco SA  Brazil's No. 2 private-sector bank  is comfortable with loan-loss provisions at current levels even as the nation's worst recession in a quarter century and fallout from a massive corruption scandal at state firms threaten to hamper earnings in coming quarters  executives said on Thursday.

column3: Bradesco to acquire HSBC Brazil unit  biggest-ever buy

column3: Barclays settles with U.S. investors over Libor manipulation
column4: Barclays Plc has agreed to pay $14 million to settle litigation by holders of its American depositary shares that it conspired with rivals to rig the Libor benchmark interest rate  causing its share price to be inflated.

column4: Barclays Plc will pay an additional $150 million to New York State's financial regulator to resolve allegations that it rigged foreign exchange trading by putting the bank's interests ahead of those of its clients  the regulator said on Wednesday.

column3: Barclays could face another $100 million fine in FX inquiry:  FT
column4: Nov 17 British bank Barclays Plc could face another $100 million fine by the New York Department of Financial Services (DFS) over forex market practices  the Financial Times reported  citing people familiar with the case.

column4: NEW YORK Barclays Plc agreed to pay $120 million to settle private U.S. litigation accusing it of conspiring with rivals to rig the benchmark interest rate known as Libor  lawyers for the plaintiffs said on Friday.

column4: Nov 10 Financial services provider Barclays  named Richard Heggie head of "High-Growth and Entrepreneurs".

column3: Barclays cuts Nigeria from EM local bond index as of February

column4: LONDON  Nov 6 (IFR) - Massive order books for this week's Tier 2 deals left the depth of demand for the asset class in no doubt  as better market conditions helped kick-start supply after it all but evaporated in the second half of the year.

column3: Barclays in $94 million Euribor accord  other banks may follow
column4: NEW YORK Barclays Plc agreed to pay $94 million to settle U.S. antitrust litigation in which investors accused 11 banks of conspiring to manipulate the benchmark European Interbank Offered Rate (Euribor) and related derivatives.

column4: NEW YORK Barclays Capital said on Thursday it will cut 36 Russian foreign currency denominated debt issues from its investment grade Global Aggregate index following Moody's Investors Service's decision to downgrade the sovereign to junk status last week.

column3: Barclays wins reversal of liability ruling in $300 mln dispute

column4: American Express Co   which said on Thursday that its credit card partnership with Costco Wholesale Corp  would end next year  is also ending its co-branded card deal with JetBlue Airways Corp   according to a published report.

column4: Feb 9 Barclays Plc is planning to raise pay for junior investment bankers as the British bank seeks to retain talent  Bloomberg News reported  citing two persons familiar with the matter.

column4: The U.S. Department of Justice is examining currency-linked investments offered by Barclays  and UBS   the Financial Times reported on Sunday.

column4: HONG KONG  Feb 3 (IFR) - Barclays has named Jack Yee head of blocks origination for Asia-Pacific  a newly created position within investment banking. In his new role  Yee reports to Jorge Munoz  head of equity capital markets for the region.

column3: Barclays to add Malaysian sukuk to flagship bond index

column3: Barclays lost 'tens of millions' of dollars on Swiss franc moves: source

Fitch placed the company's ratings on Negative Watch in March 2014  when Baxter announced it plans to spin off its BioScience business. column4: MELBOURNE  May 18 BHP Billiton Ltd   is looking to take advantage of a slump in oil prices to pick up assets where it can use its deepwater drilling expertise to boost growth as it slows expansion in onshore shale  its petroleum head said.

column4: MELBOURNE BHP Billiton is contesting A$522 million ($409 million) in Australian tax bills on its Singapore marketing operations up to 2010  after having paid almost no tax in Singapore since 2006  the global miner told an Australian Senate panel.

column4: LONDON  Feb 24 Greek shares outperformed flat European indexes on Tuesday after a list of proposed reforms submitted to international partners was received favourably by the European Commission.

column3: U.S. charges ex-Banco Santander executive with insider trading
column4: NEW YORK A former Banco Santander SA  executive has been indicted for insider trading ahead of a proposed 2010 takeover of Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc  by the mining group BHP Billiton Ltd  U.S. prosecutors said on Tuesday.

column3: BlackRock sells Kuala Lumpur mall to Malaysia's Pavilion

column4: NEW YORK A top bond manager at BlackRock Inc said he still sees value in the erratic junk-bond market  including in Europe and in the debt of companies focused on consumer goods and services.

column4: NEW YORK The U.S. Federal Reserve will likely raise interest rates twice in 2016 following the first rate hike in nearly a decade on Wednesday  said a top bond manager at BlackRock   the world's biggest asset manager.

column4: LONDON Rob Leach  former head of EMEA capital markets at BlackRock   is to lead European ECM at Jefferies [JGLL.UL] as the U.S. firm shakes up its investment banking teams  two sources familiar with the matter said on Friday.

column4: NEW YORK Top BlackRock Inc  portfolio manager Rick Rieder said on Tuesday that he still saw value in emerging markets and high-yield debt despite fears that a tighter U.S. monetary policy could trim prices further.

column4: NEW YORK Investors piled into BlackRock Inc bond ETFs and paid more in hedge fund fees in the third quarter  helping the world's largest asset manager beat Wall Street's earnings forecasts and offsetting a higher tax hit that cut profits 8 percent from a year earlier.

Air Force spokesman Major Robert Leese said the order to stop work was issued after a formal protest was filed on Nov. 6.

While DuPont is expected to report lower first-quarter results  Travelers Companies Inc's first-q

column4: MIAMI Delta Air Lines Inc  is hoping to strengthen partnerships with carriers in South Korea  Mexico and Brazil  and it has been approached about investing in Japan's bankrupt Skymark Airlines  Delta's president Ed Bastian told reporters Monday.

column3: Delta Air to take payments via Alipay from Chinese travelers

column3: U.S. regulator proposes letting Delta keep contested Tokyo airport slot

column3: Delta jet skids off runway during snowstorm at NY airport

column4: A federal mediator has been called in to revive stalled labor negotiations at Delta Airlines Inc's  Philadelphia-area refinery  as both sides seek to prevent the nation's largest U.S. refinery strike in 35 years from spreading to the East Coast.

column3: American and Delta not interested in Skymark Airlines tie-up

column3: Delta to use fuel drop to cut debt  return cash to investors
column4: With plummeting oil prices expected to cut airlines' costs by billions of dollars  Delta Air Lines Inc  said Tuesday that it will channel the savings toward debt reduction and returning more cash to shareholders.

column3: U.S. justices hostile to tribal court authority in molestation case
column4: WASHINGTON Conservative members of the U.S. Supreme Court on Monday appeared unwilling to allow a Native American tribal court to oversee a child sexual molestation lawsuit against retailer Dollar General Corp.

column3: Dollar General profit beats despite sluggish consumer spending

column4: Dollar General Corp  could make smaller acquisitions and build its store footprint to better compete with Dollar Tree Inc   which is poised to become the largest discount retailer after its acquisition of Family Dollar Stores Inc .

column4: Family Dollar Stores Inc shareholders are expected to vote in favor of a pending $8.5 billion merger with Dollar Tree Inc despite a higher offer from Dollar General still on the table  according to people familiar with the matter.

column4: WASHINGTON Some 20 state attorneys general have joined the federal antitrust investigation of competing bids by Dollar General Corp and Dollar Tree Inc to buy Family Dollar Stores  Inc  a development that potentially complicates the companies' efforts to win U.S. approval for a deal.

column4: * Total operating revenue $6.48 bln vs est $6.87 bln   (Adds details  background  CEO comment)

column3: Edwards Lifesciences lifts outlook on heart valve demand

The 1921 Martin Act  a wide-reaching state law  was dusted off in the ea

column3: Breakingviews: Exxon investors may rue climate-risk indifference
column4: By Kevin Allison and Ben Kellerman Exxon Mobil investors may regret their indifference to climate risks. The oil major's shares barely budged on news that New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman is investigating whether the company misled owners about global warming. The probe adds legal teeth to the carbon-bubble debate. Shareholders  though  seem more worried about oil prices.

column3: GE points way for 'too big to fail' peers

column3: Corporate 'siloing' an obstacle to charging GM employees: prosecutor

column3: GM expects India business to be profitable in five years

column3: UPDATE 1-Honda says to invest 200 mln pounds in UK plant

column3: Honda expands recall for Takata air bags by over 100 000 vehicles
column4: DETROIT  March 19 Honda Motor Co said on Thursday it will add more than 100 000 vehicles to a U.S. recall related to potentially defective air bags made by Takata Corp that can deploy with too much force and spray occupants with metal shards.

column3: Honda CEO to step down  replaced by low-profile engineer
column4: TOKYO Honda Motor Co  on Monday named an experienced  yet little known  engineer as its new chief executive  who will take over in late-June with the Japanese automaker battling the fallout from a slew of recalls that have shaken its reputation for quality.

column3: West Coast port dispute costing Honda 25 000 vehicles
column4: WASHINGTON Honda Motor Co  on Saturday praised an agreement to end a labor dispute at U.S. West Coast ports but said shipping delays will cost the company about 25 000 vehicles this month.

column3: Honda to slow U.S. output due to West Coast ports dispute
column4: SAN FRANCISCO Japanese carmaker Honda Motor Co Ltd  plans to slow production at some of its plants in North America due to a parts shortage caused by a partial shutdown of ports along the West Coast.

column3: Honda aims to cut car model variations by a fifth to focus on quality
column4: ASAHIKAWA  Japan Honda Motor Co is looking to reduce the number of variations on its cars by a fifth to focus more on quality  its R&D chief said  as Japan's third-biggest automaker tries to emerge from a year of product recalls and quality problems.

column3: Honda backing away from 6 million a year car sales goal: CEO
column4: ASAHIKAWA  Japan Honda Motor Co  is backing away from its goal of selling 6 million cars a year by March 2017  its chief executive said  conceding that recent quality woes may have had something to do with pressure to meet the lofty target.

column3: Exclusive: Honda CEO shrugs off critics; will see through his supply reforms
column4: Honda Motor CEO Takanobu Ito  under fire for how he is dismantling the traditional way the Japanese car maker sources parts and technologies  has resisted moves for his ouster and will fight on for another two-year term  according to four people with direct knowledge of the matter.

column3: UPDATE 1-Takata air bag lawsuits sent to Florida court
column4: NEW YORK  Feb 6 Dozens of lawsuits against Takata Corp and several car manufacturers over faulty air bags that prompted a wave of recalls will be heard in a Florida federal court  a judicial panel has ruled.

column3: UPDATE 4-U.S. regulators recall 2.1 million vehicles in new air bag issue
column4: Jan 31 The auto industry's air bag troubles deepened on Saturday as U.S. federal safety regulators said three big automakers will recall about 2.1 million older vehicles to fix defects that could cause air bags to deploy when they are not supposed to.

column3: Honda says fatal crash involved Takata air bag inflator rupture
column4: DETROIT Honda Motor Co Ltd  on Friday said it has confirmed that a Takata Corp  air bag inflator ruptured in a Jan. 18 crash in Texas that killed the driver.

column3: Driver killed in Houston crash in Honda with Takata air bags
column4: DETROIT Honda Motor Co said on Thursday that a driver was killed last week in a Houston suburb in a 2002 Accord equipped with a Takata Corp air bag that may have ruptured.

column4: BEIJING/TOKYO Honda Motor Co  has chosen a competitor of embattled Takata Corp  to supply air bags for the next North American version of its Accord sedan  the automaker's best-selling vehicle  two people with knowledge of the decision said.

column3: Nikkei rises on strong U.S. data  weak yen; Sharp tumbles on profit warning
column4: TOKYO  Jan 19 Japan's Nikkei share average rose on Monday after strong U.S.  economic data buoyed sentiment and the weaker yen helped exporters such as Honda Motor Co  but Sharp Corp tumbled on a profit warning.     The Nikkei rose 0.9 percent to 17 014.29  recovering from a 2-1/2-month low of 16 592.57 hit on Friday.     But trading was thin  with only 2.040 billion shares changing hands  the lowest since Dec. 30 as there were fewer participants with the U.S. markets shut on Monday

column3: Honda to pay $70 million for failure to report deaths  injuries
column4: WASHINGTON Honda Motor Co has agreed to pay $70 million in penalties to the U.S. government for failing to report hundreds of injuries  deaths and other consumer claims involving its cars  transportation officials said on Thursday.

column3: U.S. auto sales end 2014 strong but slower growth looms
column4: DETROIT Automakers reported strong December U.S. sales on Monday  boosted by falling gasoline prices  but industry executives and analysts cautioned that growth would slow in 2015 after five years of rapid recovery from the recession. | Video

column3: Flagging oil sector keeps pressure on industrial manufacturers

column3: IBM profit forecast  fourth-quarter revenue below estimates

column3: UPDATE 2-Brazil's Itaú buys BTG Pactual's debt collector stake  trumps rival bid
column4: SAO PAULO  Dec 31 Itaú Unibanco Holding SA  Brazil's No. 1 bank by market value  has agreed to pay Grupo BTG Pactual SA about 1.21 billion reais ($305 million) for a stake in a debt collection company and a pool of non-performing loans  in a last-minute bid that trumped a rival bid.

column3: BTG Pactual in talks over $1 billion loan sale to Itaú  Bradesco  sources say
column4: SAO PAULO Grupo BTG Pactual SA  is negotiating the sale of around 4 billion reais ($1.03 billion) in loans to rivals Itaú Unibanco Holding SA  and Banco Bradesco SA   two sources with direct knowledge of the situation said on Monday.

(Reporting by Guillermo Parra-Bernal; Editing by Meredith Mazzilli)

Fitch has also affirmed JPM's viability rating (VR) at 'a+'  support rating at  '1'  and its support rating floor (SRF) at 'A'. The Rating Outlook is Stable. column4: Federal prosecutors are pursuing criminal cases against executives from the Royal Bank of Scotland Group  and JPMorgan Chase & Co  for allegedly selling flawed mortgage securities  the Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday  citing unnamed sources.

column3: Weak trading hits JPMorgan  profit falls in three core businesses
column4: JPMorgan Chase & Co   the biggest U.S. bank by assets  reported a 6.4 percent decline in revenue and profit declines in three of its four main businesses  underscoring how weak trading markets and low interest rates have hurt banks in recent months. | Video

column3: RPT-UPDATE 1-Barclays set to name ex-JPMorgan banker Staley as new CEO
column4: Oct 12 Britain's third largest bank Barclays PLC  is close to naming former JPMorgan Chase banker Jes Staley as its new chief executive  a person with knowledge of the situation said on Monday.

column3: MOVES-JPMorgan in reshuffle of investor services team - memo

column3: JPMorgan's Jimmy Lee  a legendary rainmaker  dies
column4: Jimmy Lee  one of JPMorgan Chase & Co's  most important dealmakers  died on Wednesday  the bank's chief executive said in a statement. He was 62.

column3: JPMorgan's Jimmy Lee  a legendary rainmaker  dies
column4: Jimmy Lee  one of JPMorgan Chase & Co's  most important dealmakers  died on Wednesday  the bank's chief executive said in a statement. He was 62.

column3: MOVES-Darrant leaves BNP Paribas to join JP Morgan

column4: NEW YORK Voicemail is going the way of the typewriter  at least at JPMorgan Chase & Co .

column4: WASHINGTON U.S. regulators have subpoenaed JPMorgan Chase & Co  for all of its communications related to 35 Chinese officials  including anti-corruption chief Wang Qishan  as part of an ongoing probe into the bank's hiring practices  the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

column4: WASHINGTON U.S. regulators have subpoenaed JPMorgan Chase & Co  for all of its communications related to 35 Chinese officials  including anti-corruption chief Wang Qishan  as part of an ongoing probe into the bank's hiring practices  the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

column4: DETROIT Shareholders of JPMorgan Chase & Co  narrowly approved on Tuesday the 2014 compensation packages for CEO Jamie Dimon and other top executives in a rebuke from investors over the bank's pay practices.

column4: JPMorgan Chase & Co's  consumer and commercial banking unit said it would buy $45 billion of mortgage servicing rights from Ocwen Financial Corp .

column4: * Deutsche Bank also planning to invest in equities   (Adds JPMorgan banker comments)

column4: PARIS U.S. bank JPMorgan Chase has been placed under formal investigation in France as part of a probe into alleged tax evasion by senior managers at investment firm Wendel  a court official said on Wednesday.

column4: NEW YORK JPMorgan Chase & Co  said on Tuesday it is in "advanced stages" of settlement talks with the U.S. Department of Justice and Federal Reserve over previously disclosed investigations into its foreign exchange trading.

column4: NEW YORK U.S. prosecutors said Friday their efforts to extradite from Spain a former JPMorgan Chase & Co  executive charged in connection with the bank's $6.2 billion "London Whale" scandal had hit a dead end.

column3: Deutsche Bank said to hire Ed Reardon from JPMorgan -Bloomberg

column4: MADRID Spain on Thursday rejected a U.S. extradition request for Javier Martin-Artajo  an ex-JP Morgan Chase & Co executive indicted over the "London Whale" scandal which led to over $6 billion in trading losses in 2012.

column4: RIO DE JANEIRO Petróleo Brasileiro SA  struggling with fallout from a corruption scandal and a decline in oil prices  could release audited financial information this month despite facing "a perfect storm " analysts at JPMorgan Securities said on Tuesday.

column4: MADRID A Spanish prosecutor has recommended extradition to the United States of Javier Martin-Artajo  an ex-JPMorgan Chase & Co executive indicted over the "London Whale" scandal which led to over $6.2 billion in trading losses at the bank in 2012. | Video

column3: JPMorgan to pay $50 mln over improper mortgage practices
column4: JPMorgan Chase will pay $50 million as part of a national settlement agreement to compensate homeowners in bankruptcy over the use of robo-signing and other improper practices  the Department of Justice said on Tuesday.

column4: Feb 27 JPMorgan Chase & Co has appointed James Ferguson as head of its global alternative investment services business  the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday  citing a memo seen by MoneyBeat.

column3: Petrobras denies hiring JPMorgan for subsalt license sales
column4: SAO PAULO  Feb 27 Petróleo Brasileiro SA   denied on Friday that it has hired JPMorgan Chase & Co to handle the sale of oil exploration licenses in deep-sea areas off the coast this year.

column3: StanChart picks ex-JPMorgan executive Winters as CEO in major overhaul
column4: LONDON/HONG KONG Standard Chartered  said former JPMorgan  investment bank boss Bill Winters will take over as chief executive in June  replacing Peter Sands in a major management overhaul following two years of problems.

column3: Deutsche Bank hires Urwin from JPMorgan for investment bank
column4: NEW YORK Deutsche Bank AG  said on Wednesday that it has hired JPMorgan Chase & Co  executive Jeff Urwin to be co-head of corporate banking and securities and head of corporate finance.

column3: U.S. Justice Dept questions JPMorgan over auto lending practices
column4: NEW YORK JPMorgan Chase & Co  said on Tuesday the bank has been questioned by the U.S. Department of Justice over auto lending practices that possibly resulted in discrimination.

column3: Greek bank deposit outflows rose to 3 billion euros last week: JP Morgan
column4: LONDON Deposit outflows from Greece's banks rose last week to around 3 billion euros  according to JP Morgan estimates  ahead of Friday's last-minute aid extension agreement with the country's euro zone creditors.

column3: J.P. Morgan Securities hires eight advisers since fall
column4: NEW YORK J.P. Morgan Securities  JPMorgan Chase & Co's boutique wealth management business  said on Wednesday it hired eight advisers in the last six months who together managed $2 billion in assets at their old firms.

column3: JPMorgan tops list of risky banks: government study
column4: WASHINGTON JPMorgan Chase & Co bears the highest potential hazard to the financial system if it were to fail  a staff study released by a U.S. government research agency showed  providing a first-of-its-kind numerical risk ranking of U.S. banks.

column3: Kentucky reaches $39.5 million settlement with Purdue  Johnson & Johnson
column4: Kentucky reached two separate settlements totaling $39.5 million with Purdue Pharma and Johnson & Johnson  Attorney General Jack Conway said on Wednesday.

column3: J&J  Alphabet aim for smarter  smaller  cheaper surgical robot
column4: Johnson & Johnson and Alphabet Inc's life sciences unit have formed an independent company to create far smaller  smarter and less costly robotic-assisted systems for surgery than those sold now by other companies  J&J said on Thursday.

column3: AbbVie  J&J leukemia drug cuts death risk vs chemo in new patients: study
column4: Johnson & Johnson's and AbbVie's cancer drug Imbruvica significantly reduced the risk of death and disease progression compared with chemotherapy in previously untreated patients with a type of leukemia in a late stage study  paving the way for an expanded approval of the medicine.

column3: FDA approves J&J drug for advanced multiple myeloma
column4: U.S. regulators have approved an experimental treatment from Johnson & Johnson that may offer hope to multiple myeloma patients who have run out of other options against the blood cancer.

column3: Case to Watch: J&J asks SCOTUS to clarify preemption standard
column4: In its bid to overturn a $140 million award over Children's Motrin  Johnson & Johnson is asking the U.S. Supreme Court to clarify what constitutes "clear evidence" that federal regulators would reject proposed changes to a drug's warning label.

column3: Bi-monthly injection blocks HIV in study from J&J and GSK
column4: A long-acting two-drug injection given once every eight weeks worked as well as three daily pills in suppressing HIV  the virus that causes AIDS  according to a clinical trial backed by Johnson & Johnson and GlaxoSmithKline.

column3: FDA clears J&J's chemotherapy for certain soft tissue sarcomas
column4: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said it approved Johnson & Johnson's chemotherapy to treat specific soft-tissue sarcomas (STS) that have spread to other parts of the body or cannot be removed by surgery.

column3: Johnson & Johnson's Stelara succeeds in Phase III Crohn's disease trial
column4: Johnson & Johnson's Stelara was significantly better than placebo at inducing clinical response and remissions in patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease  according to data from a late stage trial  providing ammunition for a potential expanded approval of the medicine.

column3: More than 200 J&J talcum-powder cancer plaintiffs return to state court
column4: Oct 16 - Johnson & Johnson has lost its bid to keep three lawsuits that bring together claims from more than 200 plaintiffs alleging a link between talcum-powder products and ovarian cancer from returning to state court in St. Louis.

column3: J&J third-quarter sales miss mark  hurt by strong dollar
column4: Johnson & Johnson  reported third-quarter sales well below Wall Street estimates  hurt by the stronger dollar and disappointing demand for its Remicade arthritis drug and its Xarelto blood clot preventer. | Video

column3: J&J starts vaccine trial in Sierra Leone  even as Ebola fades
column4: Johnson & Johnson has begun a clinical trial of a two-shot Ebola vaccine in Sierra Leone  underlining its determination to push ahead with development  even as the epidemic fades out in West Africa.

column3: J&J sells popular Splenda sugar substitute to Heartland Food
column4: Johnson & Johnson  on Tuesday said it was selling its widely used Splenda sugar substitute to privately held Heartland Food Products Group in order to focus on other consumer brands.

column3: Cherokee Nation sues J&J for Risperdal refund
column4: Nearly two years after Johnson & Johnson and its Janssen Pharmaceutical unit reached a $2.2 billion settlement with the U.S. Justice Department over the marketing of the antipsychotic drug Risperdal  the drug companies are facing a similar suit by the Cherokee Nation.

column3: Interpublic reports better-than-expected revenue
column4: Advertising company Interpublic Group of Cos Inc's  revenue trumped expectations for the seventh straight quarter as higher advertising spending by U.S. businesses made up for the strong dollar's impact on international revenue.

column3: Johnson & Johnson second-quarter sales wilt on strong dollar  weak device sales
column4: Johnson & Johnson on Tuesday reported sharply lower sales in the second quarter  and cited a stronger U.S. dollar  disappointing sales of its medical devices and plunging demand for a hepatitis C drug faced with strong competition.

column3: MDL sought for Johnson & Johnson power morcellator lawsuits
column4: Lawyers for six women suing Johnson & Johnson over injuries allegedly caused by its power morcellator medical devices have sought to consolidate more than 20 similar lawsuits in Kansas federal court.

column3: Genmab shares rise on cancer drug's FDA licence application
column4: COPENHAGEN  June 8 Shares in Genmab  rose almost 3 percent on Monday after partner Johnson and Johnson's announcement late on Friday that the companies have applied to U.S. authorities for a licence to market their blood cancer drug daratumumab.

column3: FBI probing what J&J knew about uterine surgery device: WSJ
column4: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is probing a surgical tool found to spread uterine cancer and what Johnson & Johnson knew about its risks before withdrawing its version of the device last year  the Wall Street Journal reported.

column3: J&J to submit at least 10 new drugs for approval by 2019

column3: Achillion partners with J&J to develop hepatitis C drugs
column4: Achillion Pharmaceuticals Inc said it will collaborate with Johnson & Johnson to develop and market its hepatitis C drugs including an oral regimen that could work on all genotypes and shorten treatment time.

column3: FDA warns on newer class of type 2 diabetes drugs
column4: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Friday warned that a widely used newer class of type 2 diabetes drugs sold by AstraZeneca  Johnson & Johnson and Eli Lilly in partnership with Boehringer Ingleheim may cause dangerously high levels of blood acids that could require hospitalization.

column3: J&J to consult ethicists on requests for experimental drugs
column4: NEW YORK Johnson & Johnson will become the first pharmaceutical company to formally seek advice from outside medical ethicists on "compassionate use" requests  in which desperate patients ask drugmakers to let them take an experimental medication  the company announced on Thursday.

column3: Interpublic revenue beats estimates on higher U.S. ad spending
column4: Advertising agency Interpublic Group of Cos Inc's  quarterly revenue trumped expectations as higher ad spending by U.S. businesses made up for the strong dollar's impact on international revenue.

column4: * Says achieves 10 million dollar milestone in daratumumab collaboration with Janssen  a pharmaceutical company of Johnson & Johnson

column3: IBM launches new health unit  teams up with Apple  J&J  Medtronic
column4: SEATTLE International Business Machines Corp  deepening its partnership with Apple Inc to make use of health information gathered by millions of Apple devices  is creating a unit dedicated to providing data analytics to the healthcare sector.

column3: J&J  Glaxo settle U.S. lawsuit over allergy ads
column4: NEW YORK GlaxoSmithKline Plc has agreed to settle a lawsuit by Johnson & Johnson accusing it of using false advertising at the start of the U.S. allergy season to grab market share.

column3: Johnson & Johnson sues Glaxo over allergy ads as spring nears

column4: South Carolina's Supreme Court ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay a penalty of $136 million  upholding a jury's finding that the drugmaker's Janssen unit had improperly marketed its anti-psychotic drug Risperdal and concealed its risks.

column4: Cancer drug maker Pharmacyclics Inc  is exploring a sale and has attracted interest from Johnson & Johnson  and Novartis AG   Bloomberg reported.

column3: J&J's $7.2 bln claim against Boston Scientific now with U.S. judge
column4: NEW YORK  Jan 21 For more than eight years  Johnson & Johnson has pursued billions of dollars in damages against Boston Scientific Corp after the latter won a controversial - and ultimately ill-fated - bidding war for device maker Guidant.

column4: Johnson & Johnson reported lower-than-expected quarterly sales as a stronger dollar offset higher sales of the Band-Aid maker's new drugs and older treatments.

column4: Johnson & Johnson on Tuesday announced a licensing deal with Vedanta Biosciences to develop the privately held company's lead microbiome-based drug candidate for inflammatory bowel disorders  such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

column4: Johnson & Johnson will pay Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc up to $835 million for the option to license three drugs targeting autoimmune diseases in the bowel.

column4: June 10 Johnson Controls Inc wants to exit the automotive seating and interiors businesses to focus on its higher-margin building efficiency and automotive battery operations  the company said on Wednesday.

column4: Johnson Controls Inc   the largest U.S. auto parts supplier  reported a 3 percent fall in quarterly revenue  hurt by a stronger dollar.

column3: CBRE seeks to buy Johnson Controls' workplace solutions: sources
column4: CBRE Group Inc   the world's largest commercial real estate services firm  is in talks to acquire Johnson Controls Inc's  global workplace solutions business for more than $1 billion  according to people familiar with the matter.

column3: UPDATE 2-Peru regulator probes toilet paper cartel  could fine Kimberly-Clark

column4: * Shares rise as much as 5.6 pct   (Adds details  graphics; updates shares)

column3: UPDATE 1-Kimberly-Clark to transfer pension obligations to insurers
column4: Feb 23 Kimberly-Clark Corp is transferring responsibility for payment of U.S. pensions to two insurers  a move it said would cut its projected benefit obligation by about $2.5 billion but result in a charge of $800 million in the second quarter.

column3: Fitch Affirms Kimberly-Clark's IDR at 'A'; Outlook Stable
column4: (The following statement was released by the rating agency) NEW YORK  February 11 (Fitch) Fitch Ratings has affirmed Kimberly-Clark  Corporation's (KMB) ratings as follows: --Long-term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) at 'A'; --Short-term IDR at 'F1'; --$2 billion commercial paper (CP) program at 'F1'; --$200 million dealer remarketable securities at 'A'/'F1'; --$2 billion revolving credit facility at 'A'; --Senior unsecured notes and debentures at 'A'. The Rating Outlook is Stable. Approximately $6.

column3: Diaper wars: Kimberly to take on P&G through innovation  higher ad spend

column3: Diaper wars: Kimberly to take on P&G through innovation  higher ad spend
column4: Jan 23 Kimberly-Clark Corp is set to increase advertising and promotional spending for its diapers and launch new products in an escalating war with bigger rival Procter and Gamble Co in North America.

column4: NEW YORK Oil and gas pipeline operator Kinder Morgan's  shares do not appear cheap despite having fallen 60 percent this year  and could fall further before reaching fair value  U.S. weekly investment publication Barron's said in its Dec. 14 edition.

column3: UPDATE 1-Pipeline giant Kinder Morgan slashes dividend 75 percent

column3: CORRECTED-UPDATE 3-Total Port Arthur refinery cuts production after worker killed -sources

column3: Breakingviews: Oil billionaire pumps Kinder Morgan for tidy gain
column4: CHICAGO (Reuters Breakingviews) - Leave it to Harold Hamm to pump Kinder Morgan for a tidy gain. The Continental Resources boss is selling Hiland Partners  his private pipeline company  to its giant rival for $3 billion  more than enough to cover his nearly $1 billion divorce bill. The sale also eliminates a conflict of interest that arose from a 2013 deal between Hiland and Continental. Kinder Morgan  meanwhile  gets a prized - if pricey - foothold in North Dakota's Bakken shale.

column3: Lockheed wins $5.3 billion contract for C-130J aircraft

column3: Lockheed will not protest U.S. Marine Corps vehicle contracts

The work is expected to be complete by the middle of 2023 and was a result of a sole source acquisition  the U.S. Department of Defense said in its daily digest of major contract awards.

Air Force spokesman Major Robert Leese said the order to stop work was issued after a formal protest was filed on Nov. 6.

column3: Canada Liberal leader Trudeau says would scrap F-35 program

column3: Pentagon sees risk in F-35 fighter's complex logistics program
column4: NATIONAL HARBOR  Md. Long delays in Lockheed Martin Corp's development of a computer-based logistics system for the F-35 fighter jet pose the biggest threat to the U.S. Air Force's plan to declare the aircraft ready for combat next summer  the head of the Pentagon's F-35 program office said.

column3: Boeing rejects Aerojet Rocketdyne bid for ULA launch venture

column3: UPDATE 2-U.S. Air Force still evaluating options for F-35 'block buy'

column3: UPDATE 1-U.S. Army says issues stop-work order for Oshkosh truck deal

column3: Lockheed-Boeing rocket venture expands partnership with Bezos' space firm
column4: CAPE CANAVERAL  Fla (Reuters) – - United Launch Alliance (ULA)  the biggest supplier of rockets for the U.S. military  will ramp up rocket engine work with Amazon.com Inc  founder Jeff Bezos' space company  the companies said on Thursday.

column3: Lockheed to cut about 500 jobs in IT services unit

column3: Aerojet makes $2 billion offer for Lockheed-Boeing joint venture: sources

column3: First of Italy's Lockheed F-35 fighter jets completes flight

column3: Lean manufacturing transforms Wisconsin maker of U.S. Navy warships

Sept 6 Big investments  lean manufacturing techniques borrowed from the automotive industry  and a more engaged workforce have revamped the Wisconsin shipyard where Italy's Fincantieri SpA builds the Freedom variant of the U.S. Navy's coastal warships for prime contractor Lockheed Martin Corp.

column3: UPDATE 1-Saudi Arabia  U.S. near deal for two Lockheed warships -sources

column3: Lockheed wins $431 million contract for support work on F-35
column4: WASHINGTON Lockheed Martin Corp has won a contract worth $431 million to provide support equipment and services for the ninth batch of F-35 fighter jets  the Pentagon announced Monday.

column3: Lockheed welcomes U.S. plan to use its combat system for frigates
column4: MARINETTE  Wisconsin Lockheed Martin Corp on Friday welcomed the U.S. Navy's decision to use Lockheed's integrated combat system for future frigate-class ships to be built beginning in fiscal 2019  saying it would allow greater commonality across the entire Navy fleet.

column3: U.S. okays $1.5 billion sale of Lockheed Aegis combat system to Japan
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. State Department has approved the likely sale to Japan of two Lockheed Martin Corp Aegis combat systems valued at $1.5 billion  a deal aimed at boosting Japan's defenses against a ballistic missile attack  the U.S. Defense Department said Friday.

column3: U.S. approves possible sale of $5.4 billion in missiles to Saudi Arabia
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. State Department has approved the possible sale to Saudi Arabia of $5.4 billion in additional PAC-3 missiles built by Lockheed Martin Corp  the Pentagon said on Wednesday.

column3: UPDATE 1-U.S. DOJ starts criminal probe into Sikorsky Navy contract
column4: July 24 The U.S. Department of Justice has informed Sikorsky Aircraft that it has started a criminal investigation into allegations the helicopter maker overbilled the U.S. Navy for a contract  Sikorsky's parent company  United Technologies Corp  said on Friday.

column3: Lockheed wins $1.56 bln in foreign orders for PAC-3 missiles

column4: WASHINGTON Lockheed Martin Corp said Monday it would buy Black Hawk maker Sikorsky Aircraft from United Technologies Corp for $9 billion  cementing Lockheed's dominance in weapons making. | Video

column3: Exclusive: Lockheed to buy United Tech's Sikorsky for over $8 billion
column4: WASHINGTON Lockheed Martin Corp  has agreed to buy United Technologies Corp's  Sikorsky Aircraft for over $8 billion  two sources said on Sunday  cementing a deal that would confirm Lockheed's dominance in weapons making and giving the Black Hawk helicopter to the maker of the F-35 fighter jet.

column3: Lockheed wins U.S. approval to upgrade fighter jets for South Korea

column3: Lockheed in the lead to buy Sikorsky from United Tech: source
column4: Lockheed Martin Corp  is the leading candidate to buy United Technologies Corp's  Sikorsky helicopter unit in a deal that could value the business at more than $8 billion  a source familiar with the situation said on Friday.

column3: Deals of the day- Mergers and acquisitions
column4: July 9 The following bids  mergers  acquisitions and disposals were reported by 1000 GMT on Thursday:

column3: Exclusive: Lockheed  Textron final suitors for Sikorsky Aircraft - sources
column4: WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Lockheed Martin Corp  and Textron Inc  have emerged as final contenders to buy United Technologies Corp's   Sikorsky Aircraft business  which could be valued at around $8 billion  according to people familiar with the matter.

column3: U.S. skips Aegis Ashore missile test after target malfunction
column4: The U.S. Missile Defense Agency on Friday said a target malfunction caused it to abort a key intercept test of the Aegis Ashore missile defense system  built by Lockheed Martin Corp  that is due to be installed in Romania this year.

column3: Lockheed names partner for commercial sales of giant airships
column4: PARIS Lockheed Martin Corp  on Tuesday named a private firm  Hybrid Enterprises LLC  as the exclusive sales agent for its  Hybrid Airships  a new type of aircraft that company officials say could revolutionize the way oil and mining companies haul equipment to the Arctic and other remote areas without roads.

column3: Lockheed says initial contacts with France about C-130s
column4: PARIS Lockheed Martin Corp   the largest U.S. weapons maker  on Tuesday said it had been in "initial contact" with French government officials about their interest in buying some C-130J transport planes to augment a fleet of larger A400M transports built by Europe's Airbus .

column3: AIRSHOW-Big savings needed to justify F-35 block buy - Lockheed
column4: PARIS  June 15 Lockheed Martin Corp  maker of the F-35 fighter jet  said on Monday it realized it would have to generate significant savings to help justify a block buy of up to 500 aircraft beginning in fiscal 2018.

column3: AIRSHOW-Lockheed says rocket launch venture urgently needs U.S. law waiver
column4: PARIS  June 14 Lockheed Martin Corp  issued a warning on Sunday over prospects for its rocket launch joint venture with Boeing Co  saying it urgently needed the United States to waive a law banning the use of Russian engines to launch military and spy satellites.

column3: U.S. Air Force to use new Lockheed spacecraft for next satellites
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. Air Force said on Tuesday it will use Lockheed Martin Corp's updated A2100 spacecraft for the fifth and sixth U.S. missile early warning satellites  with no additional cost to its 2014 bulk purchase contract with Lockheed.

column3: UPDATE 1-U.S. Air Force says 2014 F-35 engine mishap cost $50 mln
column4: WASHINGTON  June 5 The U.S. Air Force on Friday said last year's catastrophic F-35 engine failure  which grounded the entire fleet of jets built by Lockheed Martin Corp  for a month  cost over $50 million.

column3: Lockheed wins $920 million deal for early work on next F-35 jet order
column4: WASHINGTON Lockheed Martin Corp  has won a contract valued at $920 million to start buying materials and parts for a tenth batch of 94 F-35 fighter jets  the Pentagon announced Thursday.

column3: UPDATE 1-U.S. Ex-Im Bank critics go on attack over Australian satellite deal
column4: WASHINGTON  June 3 Ramping up a campaign to shut down the U.S. Export-Import Bank  Republican lawmakers on Wednesday accused the federal export financing bank of exposing U.S. taxpayers to losses over the foundering of an Australian satellite project.

column3: UPDATE 1--Lockheed F-35s get major role in U.S. military exercise
column4: WASHINGTON  June 1 Lockheed Martin Corp's  F-35 fighter jet will play a major role in a large U.S. military exercise this week for the first time  marking another milestone for the Pentagon's largest weapons program  Air Force officials said Monday.

column3: Lockheed F-35s get first role in major military exercise

column3: UPDATE 1-Pentagon eyes 3-year block buy of F-35s from fiscal 2018
column4: WASHINGTON  May 29 The Pentagon said Friday it would talk to U.S. lawmakers about approving a three-year block buy of Lockheed Martin Corp F-35 fighter jets beginning in fiscal 2018 that would include U.S. purchases and international buyers.

column3: U.S. Air Force certifies SpaceX for national security launches
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. Air Force on Tuesday said it has certified privately held SpaceX to launch U.S. military and spy satellites  ending a monopoly held by United Launch Alliance  a joint venture of Lockheed Martin Corp and Boeing Co  since its creation in 2006.

column3: Lockheed wins $735.5 million contract for satellite work: Pentagon
column4: WASHINGTON Lockheed Martin Corp has won a $735.5 million contract to maintain and operate several U.S. military secure communications satellites  the Pentagon said in its digest of major contracts on Thursday.

column3: UPDATE 1-France mulls Lockheed C130 buy as A400M delays continue

column3: BRIEF-Saft Groupe selected by Lockheed Martin Team
column4: * Selected as advanced li-ion battery supplier to Lockheed Martin Team for U.S. Armed Services Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) program

column3: Six Lockheed F-35B jets land on ship for Marine Corps testing
column4: WASHINGTON  May 18 Six U.S. F-35B fighter jets built by Lockheed Martin Corp landed on the USS Wasp amphibious warship on Monday for two weeks of operational testing required before the Marine Corps can declare a first squadron of F-35s ready for combat use in July  according to a U.S. defense official.

column3: Exclusive: Lockheed-Boeing venture lays off 12 executives in major reorganization
column4: WASHINGTON United Launch Alliance  a joint venture of Lockheed Martin Corp  and Boeing Co   on Friday said it was cutting its executive ranks by 30 percent in December through what it called voluntary departures by 12 executives.

column3: U.S. Air Force to re-evaluate radar bids after Raytheon suit denied

column3: U.S. judge dismisses Raytheon suit to block review of rival radar bids
column4: WASHINGTON A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by Raytheon Co  freeing the U.S. Air Force to re-evaluate bids it got for a new long-range radar won by Raytheon but challenged by rivals Lockheed Martin Corp  and Northrop Grumman Corp  Lockheed said in a statement.

column3: Lockheed F-35 gets first female pilot: Air Force
column4: WASHINGTON Lieutenant Colonel Christine Mau  a U.S. Air Force pilot who    was part of the first all-female combat sortie over Afghanistan in 2011  this week became the first woman to fly the Lockheed Martin Corp F-35 jet  the Air Force said on Wednesday.

column3: U.S. House defense bill funds 12 Boeing fighters  6 Lockheed F-35s

column3: Lockheed Martin profit falls 6 percent on fewer jet deliveries
column4: Lockheed Martin Corp   the Pentagon's No. 1 weapons supplier  reported a 6 percent fall in quarterly profit  partly due to fewer aircraft deliveries.

column3: Lockheed eyes cost cuts  reputation in satellite business

column3: Rocket startup unveils battery-powered engine for small satellite launches

column3: U.S. Air Force eyes future F-35 engine and arms upgrades

column3: Pentagon vows 'demanding but fair' in F-35 talks with Lockheed

column3: U.S. to modify launch capability deal for Lockheed-Boeing venture

But even if prices rebound  octane demand will keep growing in the long term as fuel economy standards strengthen  Marathon Petroleum Corp Chief Executive Gary Heminger said on Thursday.

column3: COLUMN-Judge finds lawyer 'fatally tainted' Amex deal: Frankel

column3: UPDATE 1-Norfolk Southern rejects Canadian Pacific's revised offer

column3: CP says willing to take Norfolk bid to shareholders

column3: Ackman to join Canadian Pacific CEO in defense of rail deal

column3: Norfolk Southern hostile to Canadian Pacific's $28.4 billion bid
column4: U.S. railroad operator Norfolk Southern Corp  all but rejected a $28.4 billion acquisition offer by Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd  on Tuesday  calling it "low-premium" and warning it would face significant regulatory hurdles. | Video

column3: UPDATE 2-CP Rail touts $1.8 bln savings from Norfolk deal
column4: Nov 18 Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd said its proposed $28.4 billion acquisition of U.S. railroad operator Norfolk Southern Corp would help the combined company to save at least $1.8 billion annually.

column3: Canadian Pacific offers to buy Norfolk Southern
column4: Nov 17 Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd  <CP.N > said it has offered to buy Norfolk Southern Corp  to create a transcontinental railroad.

column3: Canadian Pacific explores Norfolk Southern takeover
column4: NEW YORK Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd  is exploring a potential acquisition of U.S. peer Norfolk Southern Corp   a person familiar with the matter said on Monday.

column3: Norfolk Southern: Joaquin may delay US East Coast crude rail delivery
column4: NEW YORK  Oct 1 Norfolk Southern Corp on Thursday warned customers along its U.S. Northeast crude rail route that deliveries may be delayed due to Hurricane Joaquin  which could threaten the East Coast in upcoming days.

column3: Norfolk South profit dented by lower coal and fuel surcharges
column4: CHICAGO U.S. railroad Norfolk Southern Corp  on Monday reported a lower quarterly net profit as coal freight shipments and fuel surcharge revenue fell  and said coal would continue to weigh on results this year.

column3: Weak coal  strong dollar undermine Norfolk Southern profit
column4: CHICAGO U.S. railroad Norfolk Southern Corp  on Wednesday reported a lower net profit  sparked by a drop in coal volumes as utilities burned more lower-cost natural gas and U.S. exporters were hurt by the strong dollar.

column3: Cheap oil  strong dollar pose challenges for U.S. railroads
column4: CHICAGO Low oil prices and the strong U.S. dollar made for a somewhat painful first quarter for major U.S. railroads CSX Corp  and Norfolk Southern Corp   and may continue to weigh on their profits.

column3: UPDATE 2-Lower coal revs hit Norfolk Southern profit; upbeat on U.S. economy
column4: CHICAGO  Jan 26 Norfolk Southern Corp  the No. 4 U.S. railroad  expects a solid U.S. economy to boost its business in 2015 but said on Monday it was too early to gauge the overall impact of lower energy prices.

column3: Northrop says U.S. Air Force picked right team for bomber contract
column4: WASHINGTON Northrop Grumman Corp said on Saturday that it won a U.S. Air Force contract to build a new long-range bomber after a very thorough selection process and it argued that a new legal brief filed by Boeing Co had no merit.

column3: Northrop Grumman maps out 'bold' vision for aerospace sector
column4: PALMDALE  Calif.  Dec 15 Northrop Grumman Corp   riding high after its selection to build the next U.S. long-range bomber  says it is investing heavily and hiring workers as part of a focused plan to unveil at least one "big  bold and ingenious" new technology each year.

column3: Northrop says it will bid if Pentagon opens GPS satellite tender
column4: PALMDALE  Calif. Northrop Grumman Corp this week said it would bid if the U.S. Air Force opens a fresh competition for next-generation GPS satellites next year  as expected  and perhaps later on a new ground control system.

column3: Northrop upbeat on E-2D early-warning sales despite UAE loss
column4: DUBAI Northrop Grumman Corp  sees possible sales of dozens of its E-2D Advanced Hawkeye airborne early warning aircraft to countries in the Gulf  Asia and North Africa in coming years  despite the loss of an order from the UAE to Sweden's SAAB AB  this week  senior company officials said.

column3: Northrop's long-range U.S. bomber work paused after protest
column4: WASHINGTON Work on a recently awarded long-range strike bomber contract to Northrop Grumman Corp has been paused after rivals Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin  protested against the selection process  the U.S. Air Force said.     Air Force spokesman Major Robert Leese said the order to stop work was issued after a formal protest was filed on Nov. 6.

column3: Boeing  Lockheed protest U.S. Pentagon's bomber award to Northrop
column4: Boeing Co  and Lockheed Martin Corp  on Friday filed a formal protest against the U.S. Air Force's contract with Northrop Grumman Corp  for a new long-range strike bomber  saying the selection process was "fundamentally flawed."

column3: Boeing nears decision on protest of U.S. bomber award to Northrop
column4: WASHINGTON Boeing Co  may decide as soon as Thursday whether to protest the U.S. Air Force's selection of Northrop Grumman Corp  to develop and build a next-generation long-range strike bomber amid signs that a challenge could be an uphill battle  according to sources familiar with the issue.

column3: Boeing says reviewing U.S. briefing on bomber contract loss
column4: WASHINGTON Boeing Co  said it was briefed on Friday by the U.S. Air Force about its selection of Northrop Grumman Corp  to build a next-generation long-range strike bomber and will decide whether to protest the contract award "in the coming days."

column3: Northrop third-quarter results top estimates  2015 profit outlook raised
column4: WASHINGTON Hours after winning a multibillion-dollar contract to build a new U.S. bomber  Northrop Grumman Corp  reported higher-than-expected quarterly revenue and earnings on Wednesday  and increased its profit outlook for the full year. | Video

column3: U.S. picks Northrop Grumman to build next long-range bomber
column4: WASHINGTON Northrop Grumman Corp  maker of the stealthy B-2 bomber  beat out a team made up of Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin Corp to develop and build a next-generation long-range strike bomber  the U.S. Defense Department said on Tuesday.

column4: WASHINGTON A federal appeals court has denied a lawsuit by Raytheon Co that sought to halt the U.S. Air Force's reevaluation of bids submitted for a new $1 billion long-range radar by Raytheon  Northrop Grumman Corp and Lockheed Martin Corp.

column3: UPDATE 1-Raytheon  Northrop await debriefs after long-range radar loss
column4: WASHINGTON Oct 22 Raytheon Co and Northrop Grumman Corp on Thursday said they had asked the government for more information about why they lost a contract to build a new long-range radar system that was awarded to Lockheed Martin Corp.

column3: Northrop Grummman names COO  streamlines business units
column4: WASHINGTON Northrop Grumman Corp  on Wednesday named the head of its electronic systems sector as chief operating officer and said it would streamline its business sectors from four to three to better align with the U.S. Defense Department's changing needs.

column4: Northrop Grumman Corp   maker of Global Hawk drones  said it could buy back up to an additional $4 billion worth of shares as part of a new buyback authorization.

column3: UPDATE 1-U.S. approves possible $1.7 bln sale of E-2D early warning planes to Japan

column3: CORRECTED-UPDATE 1-Pentagon plans long-range missile defense radar in Alaska
column4: WASHINGTON  May 22 The U.S. Defense Department on Friday announced plans to deploy a new long-range radar in central Alaska that would help the U.S. missile defense system better discern potential enemy missiles launched by Iran or North Korea and increase the capacity of interceptors in the ground in Alaska and California.

column3: U.S. Air Force to re-evaluate radar bids after Raytheon suit denied
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. Air Force on Wednesday said it would re-evaluate bids received in a $1 billion long-range radar competition after a federal court dismissed a Raytheon Co  lawsuit that sought to halt a fresh look at the bidders of its losing rivals Northrop Grumman Corp and Lockheed Martin Corp.

column3: U.S. judge dismisses Raytheon suit to block review of rival radar bids

column3: Ecuador negotiates at least 18 pct cut to Occidental award - Correa
column4: QUITO  Dec 22 The government of Ecuador obtained a discount of at least 18 percent on compensation required by a World Bank tribunal for seizing Occidental Petroleum Corp's  assets  President Rafael Correa said  adding that negotiations were ongoing.

column3: U.S. Supreme Court rejects human rights suit against Occidental
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday declined to revive a human rights lawsuit against Occidental Petroleum Corp and a security contractor that had accused them of complicity in a deadly 1998 bombing by Colombia's military of a village in the South American country.

column4: QUITO  Nov 20 Ecuador is in the final stages of an agreement with Occidental Petroleum Corp to pay the roughly $1 billion required by a World Bank tribunal for seizing the company's assets  President Rafael Correa was quoted on Friday as saying.

column3: Occidental to sell Zubair stake to Iraq's South Oil: officials
column4: BASRA  Iraq Occidental Petroleum Corp  the fourth-largest U.S. oil producer  will sell its stake in the 4-billion-barrel Zubair oilfield to Iraq's state-run South Oil Company (SOC)  Iraqi oil officials said on Wednesday.

column3: Ecuador says it will comply with Occidental arbitration award
column4: QUITO Ecuador will comply with a World Bank tribunal award to pay $1.061 billion to Occidental Petroleum Corp in compensation for seizing the company's assets  the country's finance minister said on Wednesday  adding that Ecuador would seek financing.

column3: Ecuador-Occidental arbitration award reduced to $1 billion
column4: QUITO A World Bank tribunal reduced to about $1 billion the amount Ecuador must pay Occidental Petroleum Corp  in compensation for seizing the U.S.-based company's assets  in a decision made public on Monday.

column3: Ecuador says talking to Occidental to resolve oil assets seizure
column4: QUITO  Oct 31 Ecuador is in talks with Occidental Petroleum Corp to seek an agreement over a roughly $1.77 billion award the Andean country was ordered to pay for seizing the U.S.-based company's assets in 2006  President Rafael Correa said on Saturday.

column3: BRIEF-Occidental Petroleum says 'ample room' to further cut costs
column4: * Executive Vicki Hollub says 'ample room' to further cut costs

column3: Oxy to exit North Dakota's oil fields in sale to private equity fund
column4: DICKINSON  N.D./NEW YORK Occidental Petroleum Corp  the fourth-largest U.S. oil producer  has agreed to sell all of its North Dakota shale oil acreage and assets to private equity fund Lime Rock Resources in a deal worth around $500 million  according to sources familiar with the matter.

column3: BRIEF-Occidental Petroleum's capex 'will continue to decline throughout the year'
column4: * CEO says 2016 capex budget will be lower than 2015 if oil prices stay at current levels

column3: Occidental's Chiang quits after new CEO picked
column4: HOUSTON  June 12 Occidental Petroleum Corp  told regulators on Friday that a top executive  Willie Chiang  has suddenly quit - a month after Vicki Hollub was picked to eventually replace Chief Executive Steve Chazen.

column3: Goldman cuts crude outlook and oil company forecasts
column4: Goldman Sachs has cut its long-term crude oil price forecasts and recommended investors sell shares in two major oil companies  saying that improved U.S. shale efficiency and higher production from OPEC will more than cover future demand.

column3: Brent posts weekly loss after month of gains; U.S. crude up
column4: NEW YORK Brent oil posted its first weekly loss in a month on Friday as the market fretted again about global oversupply while U.S. crude rose for an eighth straight week  helped by jobs growth data and the first storm of the hurricane season forming.

column3: Occidental Petroleum boosts 2015 production outlook
column4: Occidental Petroleum Corp  boosted its 2015 production forecast on Wednesday after reporting an adjusted quarterly profit in line with expectations as cost cuts helped balance  the recent drop in oil prices.

column3: Occidental Petroleum unveils CEO succession plan
column4: Occidental Petroleum Corp said on Tuesday that executive Vicki Hollub will replace Chief Executive Steve Chazen after "a thorough transition period."

column4: NEW YORK Oil prices eased off 2015 highs on Friday after Iraq said its crude oil exports hit a record in April  and on pressure from a stronger dollar.

column4: April 20 Occidental Petroleum Corp CEO Stephen Chazen says:

column3: U.S. oil rig count cull eases  approaches low point
column4: NEW YORK Two weeks of thin declines in the U.S. rig count have raised expectations that drilling activity is nearing a pivotal level that could dent production  bolster prices and coax idle rigs back to the field after a precipitous cull since October.

column3: Azeri SOCAR hires Phibro traders to expand London team
column4: LONDON  March 17 Azeri state-owned oil company SOCAR has hired staff from Phibro  the trading operation that Occidental Petroleum is winding down  to expand its London-based team  it said on Tuesday.

column3: Peru indigenous groups settle U.S. court claims with Occidental
column4: LIMA Indigenous villagers in Peru have reached a negotiated settlement with Occidental Petroleum Corp  which they had sued for allegedly polluting their lands over three decades  the two sides said on Thursday.

column4: DUBAI  Feb 10 State-run Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) has signed a technical agreement with U.S.-based Occidental Petroleum to develop the al-Hail and Ghasha oilfields  ADNOC said in a statement on Tuesday.

column3: Occidental CEO jokes Chevron is an unsuitable buyer; lifts stock
column4: WILLISTON  N.D. Occidental Petroleum Corp  Chief Executive Stephen Chazen quipped on Thursday that his larger rival Chevron Corp  was too poor to buy the No. 4 U.S oil producer  but the offhand remark sent Oxy's stock up anyway.

column3: Oneok on track to connect 700 wells in N. Dakota Williston shale-CEO
column4: Aug 5 U.S. natural gas company Oneok Inc's  chief executive officer said on Wednesday the company was on track to connect more than 700 wells in the Williston shale basin in North Dakota in 2015 and forecast connecting more than 600 next year.

column3: OpenText taps former Oracle hand as its new president
column4: TORONTO OpenText Corp said on Thursday it has tapped former Oracle Corp executive Stephen Murphy as its new president  giving Chief Executive Officer Mark Barrenechea more time to focus on strategy and the company's product road map.

column3: Oracle settles FTC charges that it left its customers open to hacking
column4: Oracle Corp has settled allegations by the Federal Trade Commission that it failed to notify customers about unaddressed hacking dangers when it released security updates for the estimated 850 million U.S. computers with Java SE software  the agency said on Monday.

column3: Oracle profit forecast fails to impress; shares fall
column4: Business software maker Oracle Corp on Wednesday delivered a third-quarter profit forecast that did not quite meet analysts' expectations  and the company's shares fell about 1 percent in extended trading.

column3: N.Y. state pension fund sues Oracle for political donor info
column4: New York state's public pension fund has sued Oracle Corp to force the tech giant to reveal how it spends its political donations  according to a court filing.

column3: Oracle revenue forecast disappoints as license sales continue falling
column4: Oracle Corp's  sales fell more than expected in the first quarter  hurt by a strong dollar and a continued drop in licensed software sales and the company warned revenue could fall in the current quarter even on a constant currency basis.

column3: No end in sight for Oracle  Google legal fight over Android
column4: SAN FRANCISCO Oracle Corp's long-running legal battle with Google Inc over Google's Android operating system for smartphones and other devices probably will not proceed to another trial until the middle of 2016  a U.S. judge said on Thursday.

column3: Anaplan targets SAP  Oracle in fast-growing business planning market
column4: FRANKFURT Business planning software start-up Anaplan is nipping at the heels of industry leaders SAP  Oracle and IBM  with sales of its cloud-based service tripling in each of the past three years as it seeks to shake up the market.

column3: Oracle seeks permission to update copyright lawsuit against Google
column4: Oracle Corp has asked a U.S. judge for permission to update its copyright lawsuit against Google Inc  to include the Android operating system's current market dominance.

column3: Oracle says Rimini Street copyright trial to begin in September
column4: Oracle Corp  said its copyright infringement lawsuit against software support services company Rimini Street Inc and the smaller rival's Chief Executive Seth Ravin would go to trial in September.

column3: U.S. top court declines to hear Google appeal in Oracle Java fight
column4: WASHINGTON/SAN FRANCISCO Oracle Corp  won a major legal victory on Monday in a closely watched copyright case involving the company's Java programing language as the U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear Google Inc's  appeal.

column3: Oracle extends cloud offerings  looks to compete with Amazon.com
column4: Oracle Corp founder and Executive Chairman Larry Ellison said his database company is expanding its cloud-computing offerings  bringing Oracle into more direct competition with Amazon.com Inc.

column3: David Donatelli joins Oracle from HP
column4: Oracle Corp named David Donatelli as executive vice president of its converged infrastructure business  which includes engineered systems  servers  storage and networking products.

column3: Oracle sales  profit miss estimates; shares fall

column3: Obama administration asks U.S. top court to decline Google copyright appeal
column4: WASHINGTON/SAN FRANCISCO The Obama administration on Tuesday sided against Google Inc and said the U.S. Supreme Court should not hear the company's appeal in a case against Oracle Corp with wide implications for the technology industry  according to a court filing.

column3: Google versus Oracle case exposes differences within Obama administration
column4: SAN FRANCISCO/WASHINGTON The Obama administration has been locked in internal wrangling over what position to take in high profile litigation between two American technology giants  Google and Oracle  according to multiple sources familiar with the discussions. It faces an end-of-May deadline to decide whether to take sides in a case before the U.S. Supreme Court that will have wide implications for the technology industry.

column3: Oracle CEO sees benefit if rival buys Salesforce.com
column4: REDWOOD CITY  Calif. Oracle Corp  Chief Executive Safra Catz said her company could benefit if Microsoft Corp  or another rival bought online customer relationship management firm Salesforce.com Inc .

column3: China's Tencent hits $200 billion market cap for first time
column4: BEIJING China's Tencent Holdings Ltd for the first time hit a market cap of more than $200 billion on Monday  making it more valuable than U.S. tech firms like Amazon.com Inc  IBM Corp and Oracle Corp.

column3: Federal Circuit revives part of Oracle patent used to sue Google

column4: June 2 Sometimes  as with a glorious sunset or a can't-look-away train wreck  the best thing to do is to stand back and bear witness.

Preferred shares of Petroleo Brasileiro SA  as the company is formally known  resumed a rally that has driven its price up about 60 percent over the last 30 days  ahead of a Wednesday release of audited financial st

column3: Two-decade Pfizer mission pays off for Guggenheim's deal king
column4: LONDON/NEW YORK Alan Schwartz knows how to play a long game. The executive chairman of boutique investment bank Guggenheim Partners spent almost 20 years cultivating Pfizer  boss Ian Read as a client. His strategy paid off handsomely when Guggenheim was named lead adviser for one of the biggest deals in history - Viagra-maker Pfizer's $160 billion acquisition of Botox-maker Allergan .
