column3: CORRECTED-MOVES-SunTrust Banks names Kevin Blair Corporate Treasurer (June 15)
column4: June 15 SunTrust Banks Inc said it appointed Kevin Blair as corporate treasurer  effective July 1.

column3: MOVES-Barclays  BNY Mellon  ANZ  Gatehouse  Macquarie Securities
column4: June 15 The following financial services industry appointments were announced on Monday. To inform us of other job changes  email moves@thomsonreuters.com.

column3: GE buyout-lending unit draws interest from SunTrust  Apollo  Ares: Bloomberg
column4: SunTrust Banks Inc  Apollo Global Management and Ares Management LP are considering offers for buying General Electric Co's unit that lends to private-equity firms in the United States  Bloomberg reported  citing people with knowledge of the matter.

column3: U.S. companies quicker to give board seats to activists
column4: NEW YORK Early in August  a call came into Sysco Corp  from Trian Fund Management LP  warning the food distributor that the activist hedge fund was about to disclose a large stake in the company.

column3: Sysco targets $400 million in annual operating income growth by 2018
column4: NEW YORK Sysco Corp said on Tuesday it is targeting at least $400 million in annual operating income growth by 2018 as the food distributor aims to increase deliveries to local  independent restaurants amid increased competition.

column3: UPDATE 1-Food distributor Sysco adds Peltz to its board
column4: Aug 20 Food distributor Sysco Corp added Nelson Peltz to its board  days after the activist investor disclosed a 7.1 percent stake in the company and called its shares "undervalued".

column3: Peltz's Trian picks up 7 percent stake in food distributor Sysco
column4: Activist investor Nelson Peltz's hedge fund  Trian Partners  has picked up a more than 7 percent stake in Sysco Corp  for about $1.6 billion  calling the largest U.S. food distributor's shares "undervalued".

column3: Judge sides with government in 'very traditional' Sysco ruling
column4: The federal judge who ruled last week in the Sysco Corp-US Foods merger case  effectively ending Sysco's bid  overwhelmingly sided with government regulators in their analysis of the national market.

column3: Deals of the day- Mergers and acquisitions
column4: June 29 The following bids  mergers  acquisitions and disposals were reported by 2000 GMT on Monday:

column3: U.S. judge grants FTC request to block Sysco merger with US Foods
column4: WASHINGTON Sysco Corp's  $3.5 billion merger with US Foods should be stopped for further review  a federal judge ruled on Tuesday  handing a major victory to the U.S. government in its effort to block the controversial merger.

column3: Sysco defends US Foods deal from FTC  judge skeptical
column4: Lawyers for Sysco Corp  the No. 1 U.S. food distribution company  told a judge that competition from regional rivals would prevent the company from raising prices if it is allowed to buy US Foods Inc  the market's No. 2 player.

column3: Exclusive: Sysco sees U.S. bird flu hurting egg supply up to 18 months
column4: NEW YORK Food distributor Sysco Corp said on Friday that a record U.S. outbreak of avian flu would limit its supply of eggs and chickens that lay them for nine to 18 months  based on information provided to the company by its suppliers.

column3: Exclusive: Sysco sees U.S. bird flu hurting egg supply up to 18 months
column4: NEW YORK Food distributor Sysco Corp said on Friday that a record U.S. outbreak of avian flu would limit its chicken and egg supply for nine to 18 months  based on information provided to the company by its suppliers.

column4: May 7 Papoutsanis Industrial And Commercial Of Consumer Goods Sa

column3: Sysco  FTC battle in court over merger  waiving sealed documents
column4: Lawyers for Sysco Corp and the U.S. government argued on Tuesday over whether the largest U.S. food distributor should be allowed to merge with its No. 2 rival  with the two sides relying heavily on confidential information to make their case.

column3: UPDATE 1-Food distributor Sysco's profit misses as costs rise
column4: May 4 Sysco Corp reported a lower-than-expected quarterly profit  hurt by higher costs and a strong dollar  a day before hearing begins on the Federal Trade Commission's motion to block the company's acquisition of rival US Foods Inc.

column3: Sysco says U.S. FTC got market definition wrong in merger fight
column4: Sysco Corp  urging regulatory approval of its plan to buy its biggest rival  US Foods  has criticized antitrust authorities over how they have evaluated market competition in the sector.

column3: Deals of the day- Mergers and acquisitions
column4: April 22 The following bids  mergers  acquisitions and disposals were reported by 2000 GMT on Wednesday:

column3: Rivals resist Sysco document request in US Foods merger fight
column4: Rivals of Sysco Corp  which is fighting to save its proposed merger with US Foods  have protested far-reaching subpoenas from the food service giant  according to court documents that also show one of the rivals seems to have dropped the issue.

column3: Judge in Sysco-US Foods merger fight says no protection for witnesses
column4: A judge in the fight between the U.S. government and food giant Sysco Corp over its bid to acquire rival US Foods has ruled that the names of deal critics  who helped build the government's antitrust case  must be released on a broader basis.

column3: Sysco wins round on what stays secret in battle to save merger
column4: Sysco Corp  which is fighting the U.S. government in hopes of saving a $3.5 billion merger  has won a round.

column3: Sysco  FTC battle over what stays secret in antitrust tussle
column4: Sysco Corp is accusing the U.S. government of failing to provide basic information about its witnesses in advance of a hearing that will be crucial in determining whether the food distributor can rescue its merger with rival US Foods Inc.

column3: Sysco extends interim termination date for US Foods deal
column4: Sysco Corp extended an interim termination date for closing or scrapping its controversial deal to buy US Foods to May 7  the company said on Monday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

column3: Sysco judge is Obama appointee with slim antitrust experience
column4: The federal district court judge assigned to hear the U.S. government's antitrust fight with Sysco Corp over its proposed merger with US Foods Inc is new to the bench  but has a long record of handling high-profile litigation.

column3: Sysco not in talks to settle U.S. lawsuit to stop merger -lawyer
column4: WASHINGTON Sysco Corp is not holding settlement talks with the U.S. government to resolve a lawsuit aimed at stopping a $3.5 billion merger of the food distributor and its largest rival  a lawyer for Sysco said on Friday.

column3: U.S. government sues to block Sysco takeover of US Foods
column4: NEW YORK/WASHINGTON The U.S. government filed a lawsuit on Thursday seeking to block Sysco Corp's  proposed takeover of rival food distributor US Foods Inc   saying the $3.5 billion deal would "eliminate significant competition" in the sector.

column3: Sysco hires lawers for possible merger fight with regulator
column4: WASHINGTON Food distributing company Sysco Corp  has hired top Washington litigators to defend itself if U.S. regulators file a lawsuit to stop its merger with rival US Foods  two sources close to the deal said on Wednesday.

column3: UPDATE 3-Sysco would sell 11 US Foods centers to win deal approval
column4: Feb 2 Food distributor Sysco Corp said it would sell 11 distribution centers run by takeover target US Foods Inc to far smaller rival Performance Food Group if skeptical antitrust regulators approve the merger with US Foods.

column3: Exclusive: Sysco  US Foods offer to divest 11 facilities to win FTC deal approval
column4: WASHINGTON Food distributor Sysco Corp  and its biggest rival  US Foods Inc   have offered to sell a smaller competitor 11 facilities in order to convince skeptical antitrust regulators to approve their $3.5 billion merger  a source briefed on the matter told Reuters.

column3: Exclusive: Sysco  US Foods offer to divest 11 facilities to win FTC deal approval
column4: WASHINGTON Food distributor Sysco Corp  and its biggest rival  US Foods Inc   have offered to sell a smaller competitor 11 facilities in order to convince skeptical antitrust regulators to approve their $3.5 billion merger  a source briefed on the matter told Reuters.

column3: Regulators may delay approval for Sysco-U.S. Foods deal: NY Post
column4: Sysco Corp   the biggest U.S. food distributor  may have to wait longer for its $8.2 billion deal to buy US Foods Inc [USFOO.UL] to be approved by regulators  the New York Post reported.

column3: Taiwan stocks fall; TSMC soars on strong earnings
column4: TAIPEI  Jan 16 Taiwan stocks fell 0.5 percent on Friday morning  but TSMC surged on news the world's biggest contract chip maker reported a record 40 percent jump in 2014 net profit.      The main TAIEX index slipped to 9 124.78 as of 0220 GMT  erasing gains at the opening bell.     Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) was up 4.6 percent  after opening 6.5 percent higher.      Overall electronics shares were up 0.3 percent  while banks lost 1.2 percent.      The Taiwan dollar

column3: Apple chipmaker TSMC eyes China production expansion
column4: TAIPEI Apple Inc chip supplier TSMC reported record net profit on Thursday and said the proliferation of low-priced  chip-hungry smartphones in China could see the company expand production in the world's biggest handset market.

column3: UPDATE 1-Taiwan's TSMC exits LED lighting business with $26 mln unit sale
column4: TAIPEI  Jan 9 Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd has agreed to sell its LED lighting unit to local firm Epistar Corp in a $26 million deal that will allow both Taiwanese companies to focus on their core business.

column3: Judge boots 'pay for delay' suits over Takeda's Actos
column4: A federal judge in New York on Tuesday dismissed more than a dozen consolidated class actions filed by health and benefit plans across the country against brand-name pharmaceutical firm Takeda and the makers of generic versions of Takeda's diabetes drug Actos.

column3: UPDATE 1-Nintendo promotes executive to replace late President Iwata
column4: * Takeda  Miyamoto remain representative directors   (Adds background on Kimishima and analyst comment)

column3: Nestle names Takeda's Francois-Xavier Roger as new CFO
column4: ZURICH  June 23 Swiss food group Nestle  on Tuesday named Frenchman Francois-Xavier Roger as its new chief financial officer and executive vice president as of July 1.

column3: Orexigen says obesity drug safety trial terminated
column4: A trial assessing the cardiovascular safety of obesity drug Contrave  made by Orexigen Therapeutics Inc and Takeda Pharmaceutical Co Ltd  was terminated on Tuesday due to unauthorized release of study data.

column3: After clinching $2.4 bln Actos deal  lawyers gear up for claims process
column4: Now that Takeda Pharmaceutical has agreed to pay $2.4 billion to resolve the bulk of litigation over its diabetes drug Actos  plaintiffs' lawyers are gearing up for the months-long process of determining compensation for nearly 9 000 eligible plaintiffs.

column3: BRIEF-Takeda says to buy select portfolio from Turkey's Neutec
column4: * Says to buy select portfolio from Neutec to enhance its business in Turkey

column3: Exclusive: Target in initial development of own mobile wallet - sources
column4: Target Corp is in the early stages of developing its own mobile wallet  three people familiar with the matter said  joining Wal-Mart Stores Inc in posing a threat to recent entrants like Apple Pay.

column3: UPDATE 4-Target in $39.4 mln settlement with banks over data breach
column4: Dec 2 Target Corp has agreed to pay $39.4 million to resolve claims by banks and credit unions that said they lost money because of the retailer's late 2013 data breach.

column3: Target in $39.4 mln settlement with banks over data breach
column4: Target Corp has agreed to pay $39.4 million to resolve claims by banks and credit unions that said they lost money because of the retailer's late 2013 data breach.

column3: Target website down on Cyber Monday traffic
column4: Discount retailer Target Corp's website was down due to heavy traffic on Cyber Monday.

column3: Target's online sales growth slows; margins pressured
column4: CHICAGO Target Corp  faces margin pressure and will not meet its fiscal-year forecast for online sales growth  which slowed in the latest quarter  the discount retailer said on Wednesday  sending its shares down more than 5 percent.

column3: Target co-founder Bruce Dayton dies at 97
column4: Bruce Dayton  co-founder of Target Corp  died on Friday in Orono  Minnesota  the state's governor's office said.

column3: Target to start Black Friday deals five days early
column4: CHICAGO Target Corp  said on Monday it will launch its Black Friday promotions five days early  with 10 days of deals on electronics  toys and apparel in stores and online starting Nov. 22.

column3: Target loses latest round in effort to prevent pharmacy workers from forming union
column4: Nov 5 Target Corp has lost another round in its attempt to prevent pharmacy workers at a New York City store forming what would be the first union in the retailer's 113-year history after a U.S. labor agency declined to review its objections to the plan.

column3: Target to offer free U.S. shipping  strikes global shipping deal
column4: NEW YORK Target Corp  said it will drop shipping fees for all online orders during the holiday shopping season for a second year in a row  ratcheting up competition with rivals including Wal-Mart Stores Inc  and Amazon.com .

column3: Target to match online prices with over two dozen online rivals
column4: Target Corp said it will match online prices of 29 of its rivals including Amazon.com and Wal-Mart Stores Inc  as the race to grab shoppers intensifies ahead of the  holiday season.

column3: Target appoints new operations leader to identify customer needs faster
column4: CHICAGO Target Corp on Thursday appointed Anu Gupta to a newly created operational role that is expected to help the retailer  anticipate customer needs quickly.

column3: Exclusive: Target pharmacy workers form union  first in company's history
column4: CHICAGO A group of pharmacy workers within Target Corp's store in Brooklyn  New York  have won a vote to form a microunion  making it the first unionized store at the retailer since its inception in 1902.

column3: Target pharmacy workers form union  first in company's history
column4: CHICAGO A group of pharmacy workers within Target Corp's store in Brooklyn  New York  have won a vote to form a microunion  making it the first unionized store at the retailer since its inception in 1902.

column3: U.S. judge certifies class action over Target Corp data breach
column4: A U.S. judge on Tuesday certified a class action against Target Corp  brought by several banks over the retailer's massive data breach in 2013.

column3: Target to drop Cherokee brand products in U.S. from 2017
column4: Apparel retailer Cherokee Global Brands  said Target Corp  elected not to renew the license of the Cherokee brand in the United States  sending the company's shares tumbling 33 percent in extended trading.

column3: Target settles with U.S. on charge of race  gender bias in hiring
column4: Target Corp has agreed to pay $2.8 million to settle a U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) charge that it used hiring tests that disproportionately screened out candidates for various professional positions based on race and gender.

column3: RPT-New Target COO's headache: Too few goods to keep shelves filled
column4: CHICAGO  Aug 19 Two days after being promoted to the new position of Target Corp's Chief Operating Officer  John Mulligan's big job is clear: fix a supply chain that the company blamed for shortages of goods that are undermining sales growth.

column3: Target's quarterly sales outlook disappoints; shares dip
column4: CHICAGO Target Corp  forecast disappointing sales for this quarter and said it expected consumer demand to remain choppy  causing its shares to give up early gains. | Video

column3: Target reaches agreement with Visa over data breach
column4: Target Corp  said it has reached an agreement with Visa Inc  card issuers to reimburse up to $67 million in costs related to a data breach at the retailer in 2013  according to a source familiar with the matter.

column3: Target promotes CFO John Mulligan to newly created COO role
column4: Target Corp  promoted Chief Financial Officer John Mulligan to the newly created role of chief operating officer  and appointed Express Scripts Holding Co's  CFO  Cathy Smith  as his replacement.

column3: Target Corp merchandising executive Jose Barra to leave
column4: Retailer Target Corp said its vice president in charge of household supplies  electronics and sporting goods was leaving as the company narrows its focus to products such as apparel  wellness products and children's items.

column3: CVS-Target deal could spur supermarkets to find pharmacy partners
column4: CHICAGO Target Corp's  sale of its in-store pharmacies to CVS Health Corp  may encourage large supermarket chains with struggling pharmacies to look for professional drug store partners of their own.

column3: UPDATE 3-Target announces share buyback  dividend boost after disclosure snafu
column4: June 9 Target Corp said it would double its share buyback program to $10 billion and boost its quarterly dividend by 7.7 percent  confirming the contents of a statement it published inadvertently and took off its website earlier on Tuesday.

column3: UPDATE 2-Target pulls announcement on share buyback  dividend from website
column4: June 9 Target Corp took down a release from its website on Tuesday that said the company would raise its share buyback program by $5 billion and boost its quarterly dividend by 7.7 percent to 56 cents per share.

column3: Cost of data breaches increasing to average of $3.8 million  study says
column4: The cost of data breaches is rising for companies around the world as sophisticated thieves target valuable financial and medical records  according to a study released on Wednesday.

column3: MasterCard  Target data breach settlement falls apart
column4: A proposed $19 million settlement between MasterCard Inc and Target Corp over the retailer's 2013 data breach fell through after not enough banks accepted the deal  the credit card company said on Thursday.

column3: Target profit tops estimates on healthy sales growth
column4: Target Corp  on Wednesday reported a larger-than-expected rise in quarterly profit  citing robust online sales and strong demand for products at the center of its growth plan.

column3: Target to give less priority to top packaged food suppliers: WSJ
column4: Retailer Target Corp  has informed top suppliers of packaged foods  such at Kraft Foods Group Inc   that it plans to put less money into promoting their products in favor of fresher  healthier foods  the Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday.

column3: Wage increases in focus ahead of retail earnings
column4: Labor expenses will be a key focus during retailers' earnings conference calls in the coming weeks  with many companies under pressure to boost workers' wages at a time when low U.S. unemployment levels have given workers more leverage.

column3: Wage increases in focus ahead of retail earnings
column4: Labor expenses will be a key focus during retailers' earnings conference calls in the coming weeks  with many companies under pressure to boost workers' wages at a time when low U.S. unemployment levels have given workers more leverage.

column3: UPDATE 1-Canadian Tire to buy 12 Target property leases in Canada
column4: May 6 Retailer Canadian Tire Corp Ltd  said it would buy leases for 12 properties previously held by the Canadian unit of Target Corp for $17.7 million.

column3: Banks seek to block Target's deal with MasterCard over data breach
column4: A group of small banks and credit unions suing Target Corp over its massive data breach in 2013 are moving to block the retailer's proposed $19 million settlement with MasterCard Inc  calling it a "sweetheart deal" aimed at undercutting their own claims for losses.

column3: Target announces $19 mln data breach settlement with MasterCard
column4: Target Corp said it had agreed to reimburse about $19 million to financial institutions that had issued MasterCard-branded cards that were a part of the massive data breach at the retailer in 2013.

column3: Target announces $19 mln data breach settlement with MasterCard
column4: Target Corp said it had agreed to reimburse about $19 million to financial institutions that had issued MasterCard-branded cards that were a part of the massive data breach at the retailer in 2013.

column3: Target nears $20 million MasterCard data breach settlement: WSJ
column4: Target Corp is nearing a settlement with MasterCard Inc to reimburse financial institutions about $20 million for costs incurred from the retailer's massive data breach in 2013  the Wall Street Journal reported.

column3: New York questions big retailers over 'on-call' staffing
column4: By Supriya Kurane  Siddharth Cavale  Karen Freifeld  David Morgan and Nathan Layne

column3: Target to close Canadian stores by April 12
column4: Target Corp's Canadian unit said it would close the last of its 133 retail stores on April 12.

column3: UPDATE 2-GNC Holdings settles herbal supplements dispute with NY Attorney General
column4: * NY AG test also confirms GNC's products meet FDA guidelines

column3: After Target wage hike  labor groups turn to drugstore chains
column4: CHICAGO Some labor groups looking to broaden their push for minimum wage hikes after success at big U.S. retailers including Target Corp  are preparing to take on drugstore chains.

column3: Target agrees to pay $10 million to settle lawsuit from data breach
column4: WASHINGTON Target Corp  has agreed to pay $10 million in a proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit related to a huge 2013 data breach that consumers say compromised their personal financial information  court documents show. | Video

column3: Target to lift minimum wage to $9 an hour  matching rivals
column4: Target Corp next month will raise the minimum wage for all of its workers to $9 an hour  matching moves made by rivals including Wal-Mart Stores Inc and TJX Cos  a source familiar with the matter said.

column3: CORRECTED-UPDATE 2-Target to cut thousands of jobs as seeks to cut costs by $2 bln
column4: March 3 U.S. retailer Target Corp  which has been battling back after a massive data breach and sluggish performance  on Tuesday said it will eliminate several thousand jobs  mainly from headquarters locations in the United States and India  as it aims to cut $2 billion in costs over two years.

column3: CORRECTED-UPDATE 2-Target to cut thousands of jobs as seeks to cut costs by $2 bln
column4: March 3 U.S. retailer Target Corp  which has been battling back after a massive data breach and sluggish performance  on Tuesday said it will eliminate several thousand jobs  mainly from headquarters locations in the United States and India  as it aims to cut $2 billion in costs over two years.

column3: UPDATE 2-Target to cut thousands of jobs as seeks to cut costs by $2 bln
column4: March 3 U.S. retailer Target Corp  which has been battling back after a massive data breach and sluggish performance  on Tuesday said it will eliminate several thousand jobs  mainly from headquarters locations in the United States and India  as it aims to cut $2 billion in costs over two years.

column3: Target beats and sales forecasts in sign strategy working
column4: U.S. retailer Target Corp  reported a stronger-than-expected jump in fourth-quarter sales and profits and forecast modest growth this quarter in a sign that its online business strategy and focus on promoting select categories is working.

column3: Target halves order size for free shipping to $25
column4: Target Corp halved the size of online orders eligible for free shipping to $25  undercutting Amazon.com Inc and traditional rival Wal-Mart Stores Inc as it focuses on its online business.

column3: RPT-Wal-Mart wage hike seen pressuring Target  fast-food
column4: Feb 19 Wal-Mart Stores Inc's wage hike will likely trigger a rethink on pay across the retail and fast-food sectors  with Target Corp one of the low-wage employers facing pressure to follow suit and pay workers more.

column3: Four retailers pull some dietary aids off shelves after probe: NYT
column4: Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc  Wal-Mart Stores Inc  GNC Holdings Inc and Target Corp agreed to remove certain dietary supplements off their shelves in New York after receiving a threat of legal action from the state's attorney general  the New York Times reported.

column3: UPDATE 1-Target replaces cybersecurity chief with Tesco veteran
column4: Feb 3 Target Corp on Tuesday named former Tesco PLC executive Mike McNamara as chief information officer to replace Bob DeRodes  who was hired in May to bolster the retailer's cybersecurity following a massive data breach in late 2013.

column3: Thin crowds during CEO's visit helped seal Target Canada's demise
column4: NEW YORK/TORONTO Target Corp  was scrambling for ways to fix its failing Canadian expansion and considering closing just the weakest locations  but a pre-holiday visit to several stores by CEO Brian Cornell helped seal the decision for a full retreat.

column3: In surprise move  Target exits Canada and takes $5.4 billion loss
column4: TORONTO Target Corp  will exit the Canadian market after less than two years in a surprise retreat that will throw more than 17 000 employees out of work and trigger a $5.4 billion quarterly loss. | Video

column3: UPDATE 3-Obama seeks enhanced cybersecurity laws to fight hackers
column4: WASHINGTON  Jan 13 President Barack Obama sent a bill to Congress on Tuesday to strengthen U.S. cybersecurity laws to protect government  businesses and consumers while protecting privacy  after recent hacking attacks against Sony Pictures  Home Depot Inc and Target Corp   and on Monday the federal government itself.

column3: UPDATE 2-Obama seeks enhanced cybersecurity laws to fight hackers
column4: WASHINGTON  Jan 13 President Barack Obama on Tuesday renewed a push to beef up U.S. cybersecurity laws after recent headline-grabbing hacking attacks against companies like Sony Pictures  Home Depot and Target.

column3: CommScope to buy most of TE Connectivity's network business
column4: Telecom equipment maker CommScope Holding Co Inc  said it would buy nearly all of Swiss electronics firm TE Connectivity's network gear business for about $3 billion to expand in Europe and Asia.

column3: TE Connectivity nears deal to sell network business to CommScope: WSJ
column4: Swiss electronics company TE Connectivity Ltd is said to be nearing a deal to sell its network equipment unit to CommScope Holding Co Inc for about $3 billion  the Wall Street Journal reported  citing people familiar with the matter.

column3: Mexico telecoms regulator backs AT&T and Telefonica spectrum deal
column4: MEXICO CITY Mexico's telecoms regulator on Thursday said it had approved swaps of frequency blocks and a spectrum rental deal between AT&T Inc and Telefonica SA  the main competitors to the country's dominant player  Carlos Slim's America Movil.

column3: Spain's Telefonica aims to grow revenues  core profits and cash flow
column4: MADRID  Nov 30 Spain's Telefonica plans to grow revenues  core profits and cash flow in the years to 2020  Chairman Cesar Alierta said on Monday.

column3: Telefonica says Mexican arm could be candidate for flotation
column4: BARCELONA  Nov 11 Spain's Telefonica is committed to staying in the Mexican market and sees its subsidiary there as an attractive candidate for a share market flotation  the group's finance chief said on Wednesday.

column3: REFILE-Mexico's Telefonica unit given record fine over quality
column4: MEXICO CITY  Nov 9 Mexico's telecommunications regulator on Monday fined a unit of Spain's Telefonica a record 410.9 million Mexican pesos ($25 million) for not complying with quality controls.

column3: Vivendi CEO does not rule out raising stake in Telefonica
column4: CERNOBBIO  Italy The chief executive of Vivendi did not rule out on Saturday that the French media group may raise its stake in Spain's Telefonica in the future  but said there was no plan to increase its holding in Telecom Italia.

column3: Spain's Telefonica says gaining market share in Brazil
column4: SANTANDER  Spain  Aug 31 Spanish telecoms company Telefonica is gaining market share in Brazil  Chief Operating Officer Jose Maria Alvarez-Pallete told journalists  as he played down the significance of a recession in the Latin American country.

column3: Fitch Revises Telefonica SA's Outlook to Stable; Affirms at 'BBB+'

column3: Black children less likely to get pain drugs for appendicitis

column4: May 1 TransCanada Corp  Canada's second largest pipeline operator  reported a 10 percent rise in comparable earnings  helped by the positive impact of a stronger U.S. dollar on its U.S. pipeline operations and profits at its power businesses.

column3: UPDATE 1-TransCanada seeks U.S. permit on Upland line as Keystone waits
column4: CALGARY  Alberta  April 24 TransCanada Corp   whose controversial Keystone XL pipeline project has waited more than six years for U.S. approvals  is asking the Obama administration to approve another pipeline  one that would take American crude oil into Canada.

column3: Exclusive: Gatekeeper of Canada's Energy East pipeline has mixed environmental record
column4: A company pivotal to Canada's most ambitious oil pipeline project has a mixed environmental record of spills and regulatory warnings  according to government documents reviewed by Reuters  a finding likely to bolster activist opposition to the proposal.

column3: CERAWEEK-TransCanada mulls moving Canadian crude to Louisiana -exec
column4: HOUSTON  April 21 TransCanada Corp is mulling ways to get Canadian crude to Louisiana refineries now that the company has forged a deal to increase its reach to southeast Texas Gulf Coast plants  its head of liquids pipelines said on Tuesday.

column3: UPDATE 1-Magellan Midstream  TransCanada to develop Houston pipeline
column4: April 14 Magellan Midstream Partners LP  and TransCanada Corp   Canada's second-largest pipeline company  said on Tuesday they will develop a pipeline to connect TransCanada's Houston tank terminal to Magellan's East Houston terminal.

column3: UPDATE 1-TransCanada looking at oil port sites outside Quebec
column4: TORONTO  April 8 TransCanada Corp will widen its search for sites for an oil-pipeline export terminal outside Quebec after scrapping plans to build one in the province due to environmental concerns  the company's chief executive said on Wednesday.

column3: TransCanada applies Keystone's lessons to Energy East pipeline
column4: CALGARY  Alberta After six years battling bitter opposition to its Keystone XL pipeline project in the United States  TransCanada Corp has learned where and when to pick its fights  to consult early and often - and to retreat when prudent.

column3: UPDATE 3-TransCanada scraps Quebec oil port  delays Energy East pipeline
column4: CALGARY  Alberta  April 2 TransCanada Corp   the company behind the controversial Keystone XL pipeline  is scrapping plans for a Quebec oil-export terminal because of danger to whales in the St. Lawrence River  a move that is a victory for environmentalists and which delays the company's C$12 billion ($9.5 billion) Energy East pipeline project.

column3: TransCanada will not build oil export terminal in Quebec - news report
column4: TORONTO  April 1 TransCanada Corp has decided not to build a proposed oil export terminal in Quebec as part of its C$12 billion ($9.5 billion) Energy East pipeline  opting to ship the crude from Alberta to another terminal in New Brunswick  the La Presse newspaper reported on Wednesday.

column3: Exclusive: Canada regulator probing TransCanada over safety allegations
column4: (This March 18 story corrects paragraph nine to show audit had been scheduled  not prompted by allegations)

column3: Quebec aboriginals say TransCanada pipeline review flawed
column4: OTTAWA The Canadian government's review of TransCanada Corp's proposed Energy East pipeline is deeply flawed  Quebec aboriginal leaders said on Thursday  signaling they could line up with opponents of the C$12 billion ($9.43 billion) project.

column3: CANADA STOCKS-TSX declines as investors are cautious ahead of Fed
column4: TORONTO  March 18 Canada's main stock index slipped on Wednesday as investors were nervous ahead of Federal Reserve comments expected to clarify the U.S. central bank's plans to raise interest rates.

column3: Senate fails to override Obama's veto of Keystone XL approval
column4: WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate failed on Wednesday to override President Barack Obama's veto of legislation approving the Keystone XL oil pipeline  leaving the controversial project to await an administration decision on whether to permit or deny it.

column3: Obama vetoes Keystone XL pipeline  leaving it in limbo
column4: WASHINGTON President Barack Obama on Tuesday  as promised  swiftly vetoed a Republican bill approving the Keystone XL oil pipeline  leaving the long-debated project in limbo for another indefinite period. | Video

column3: Obama vetoes Keystone XL pipeline  leaving it in limbo

column3: TransCanada profit beats estimates  boosts dividend

column3: TransCanada says to decide on Quebec oil terminal by March 31

column3: Oil's price plunge could raise Keystone carbon footprint -EPA

column3: Keystone XL advances in U.S. Senate  faces Obama veto

column4: WASHINGTON Democrats in the U.S. Senate blocked the Keystone XL pipeline bill from moving forward on Monday  but supporters of the project vowed to push ahead and eventually get a vote on the measure.

column3: Keystone clears hurdles  stage set for Washington showdown

column3: Twitter bans blood drives in offices worldwide until gays can donate

column3: Steve Ballmer takes 4 percent stake in Twitter  owns more than CEO

column3: Twitter poaches Google executive Kordestani for chairman post

column3: Twitter announces layoffs as CEO Dorsey looks to revive growth

column3: Breakingviews: Wal-Mart's gun sales are shareholders' business
column4: NEW YORK  Feb 9 (Reuters Breakingviews) - Wal-Mart Stores'  gun sales are shareholders' business. The U.S. mega-retailer claims a Wall Street church's request for an arms-peddling policy is overly meddlesome. Add that to the list of excuses companies use to keep investor ideas off proxy ballots. True  lots of proposals are far out  but ones that raise issues that can affect investors deserve a vote. It's up to the Securities and Exchange Commission to define the difference.

column3: Hedge fund Pershing Square wins board seat at Zoetis
column4: BOSTON Hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management won one seat on the board of directors of animal health company Zoetis Inc and agreed with management to select a second "mutually agreeable" director  Zoetis said on Wednesday.
